body_html:
I checked this on a clean nvidia docker image and I cannot reproduce the problem. Here are the commands I ran:

$ nvidia-docker run -it nvidia/cuda:8.0-cudnn5-devel-ubuntu16.04 bash
# apt-get update
# apt-get install python3-pip
# pip3  install --ignore-installed --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/gpu/tensorflow_gpu-1.2.0rc1-cp35-cp35m-linux_x86_64.whl
# python3
>>> import tensorflow as tf
>>> tf.__version__
'1.2.0-rc1'

There are bugs around anaconda where sometimes it cannot install a new version even when --upgrade flag is provided. It is possible you are running into one of these.
You should be able to check again on a clean conda environment.

As I cannot reproduce this, I will close this bug as not reproducible.

body:
I checked this on a clean nvidia docker image and I cannot reproduce the problem. Here are the commands I ran:
```
$ nvidia-docker run -it nvidia/cuda:8.0-cudnn5-devel-ubuntu16.04 bash
# apt-get update
# apt-get install python3-pip
# pip3  install --ignore-installed --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/gpu/tensorflow_gpu-1.2.0rc1-cp35-cp35m-linux_x86_64.whl
# python3
>>> import tensorflow as tf
>>> tf.__version__
'1.2.0-rc1'
```

There are bugs around anaconda where sometimes it cannot install a new version even when `--upgrade` flag is provided. It is possible you are running into one of these.
You should be able to check again on a clean conda environment.

As I cannot reproduce this, I will close this bug as not reproducible.
